headline.main: RESHAPING SET IN MANAGEMENT OF SHUTTLE FLEET

results.snippet: The National Aeronautics and Space Administration today announced a new management structure designed to strengthen the space shuttle program and to eliminate the flaws discovered after the Challenger disaster.   Rear Adm. Richard H. Truly,...

byline.original: Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: The National Aeronautics and Space Administration today announced a new management structure designed to strengthen the space shuttle program and to eliminate the flaws discovered after the Challenger disaster. Rear Adm. Richard H. Truly, associate administrator for space flight, said the changes were designed to provide ''very clean program lines of communication and authority'' so that ''everybody knows precisely who they work for and who works for them.''

results.snippet: TO SPACE & BACK By Sally Ride with Susan Okie. Illustrated. 96 pp. New York: Lothrop, Lee & Shepard. $14.95. (Ages 6 and up)  YOUR FUTURE IN SPACE The U.S. Space Camp Training Program. By Flip and Debra Schulke and Penelope and Raymond McPhee....

headline.main: Finding Solace In a Game Vision

results.snippet: To the Sports Editor:   Recently I watched my Boston Red Sox, one out away from a championship, fail once again. It was an agony of frustration and disappointment.
results.lead_paragraph: To the Sports Editor: Recently I watched my Boston Red Sox, one out away from a championship, fail once again. It was an agony of frustration and disappointment.

headline.main: NASA WITHHOLDS PHOTOS OF CHALLENGER CABIN

results.snippet: The National Aeronautics and Space Administration said today that it would not make public photographs of wreckage from the space shuttle Challenger's crew cabin because the pictures would be ''exceedingly disturbing'' to the families of the seven...
results.lead_paragraph: The National Aeronautics and Space Administration said today that it would not make public photographs of wreckage from the space shuttle Challenger's crew cabin because the pictures would be ''exceedingly disturbing'' to the families of the seven astronauts who were aboard. The decision, made in response to requests made by news organizations under the Freedom of Information Act, was disclosed as NASA allowed reporters and photographers to tour a building where the rest of the wreckage of the spaceship was being prepared for storage. Laid out on a large grid, the barnacle-encrusted wreckage provided testimony to the aerodynamic forces that tore the shuttle apart on Jan. 28, killing the seven astronauts.

headline.main: A NEW LEADER EMERGES FROM SHADOW OF MANES

results.snippet: AS Education Secretary William J. Bennett posed recently for photographs with third graders of Public School 98 in Douglaston, Queens, a Federally designated exemplary school, an aide to Queens Borough President Claire Shulman suggested that she...
results.lead_paragraph: AS Education Secretary William J. Bennett posed recently for photographs with third graders of Public School 98 in Douglaston, Queens, a Federally designated exemplary school, an aide to Queens Borough President Claire Shulman suggested that she get into the picture. Most politicians facing election the following week would have done so. But Mrs. Shulman, who was seeking to serve the remaining three years of the late Donald R. Manes's term, did not move. ''This is their day,'' she said. The incident revealed much about her reserved, apolitical style, which contrasts sharply with that of her gregarious predecessor.

headline.main: TEST FOR SHUTTLE TERMED A SUCCESS

results.snippet: Five astronauts boarded a space shuttle today for the first time since the Challenger disaster, but the mock countdown aboard the shuttle Atlantis was halted 25 seconds short of the simulated engine firing by problems with computer software.  ...
results.lead_paragraph: Five astronauts boarded a space shuttle today for the first time since the Challenger disaster, but the mock countdown aboard the shuttle Atlantis was halted 25 seconds short of the simulated engine firing by problems with computer software. Several other troubles that might have halted a real launching cropped up, but Jim Ball, a spokesman for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, said officials considered the test successful because it accomplished its main goal: maintaining the efficiency of the launching team in the long flightless period since the Challenger exploded last Jan. 28, killing the shuttle's seven crew members. Comdr. Robert L. Gibson of the Navy, who commanded the astronaut crew aboard the Atlantis, termed the test ''a morale booster, even though it was a simulation, and a real morale booster for the launch team.''

headline.main: SAFETY TEST OF SPACE SHUTTLE MOST EXTENSIVE IN PROGRAM

results.snippet: In a test today prompted by the explosion of the space shuttle Challenger, a simulated fuel leak in the shuttle Atlantis set off a emergency evacuation of the launching pad, complete with an astronaut faking injuries.   It was the most extensive...
results.lead_paragraph: In a test today prompted by the explosion of the space shuttle Challenger, a simulated fuel leak in the shuttle Atlantis set off a emergency evacuation of the launching pad, complete with an astronaut faking injuries. It was the most extensive safety exercise in the history of the shuttle program. ''It was highly successful,'' said the launching director, Gene Thomas. ''We won't know until in the morning all of the things we feel like we need to improve. The simulation was very real. It was well orchestrated by those people in charge. I felt almost like I was in the firing room with an emergency going on. We've already talked about some of the improvements we can make, most of them in the means of communicating.''

results.snippet: FOR AS long as most of us can remember, children have been asked the mind-numbing question, ''What do you want to be when you grow up?''   Since they are resilient and creative, children learn to deal with this intrusive query with such culturally...

byline.original: By JOYCE S. ANDERSON; Joyce S. Anderson, who lives in Margate, is a management consultant, a free-lance writer and former professor of sociology at Atlantic Community College in Mays Landing. She is also the mother of Steven, David and Faith Anderson

results.lead_paragraph: FOR AS long as most of us can remember, children have been asked the mind-numbing question, ''What do you want to be when you grow up?'' Since they are resilient and creative, children learn to deal with this intrusive query with such culturally approved responses as ''a doctor'' (why not go for the No. 1 prestige and money?), ''the President'' or ''a movie star'' (interchangeable in some young heads these days), ''gourmet chef'' (now there's a sophisticate) and ''computer analyst'' (a pragmatic choice). A range of occupations from the adventurous (''astronaut'') to the prosaic (''stockbroker'') flows without hesitation from the lips of the youngest tot. Have they been primed, coached, influenced and molded by their parents, relatives and television too soon? Of course. Will their designated choice last? Perhaps. One thing is sure: The good old days of responses such as ''fireman [ now called firefighters ] , farmer, teacher, policeman [ now called police officers ] and nurse'' are long gone. These kids have moved ahead with the times.
